summary: This is an internal email forwarding a journalist's inquiry about why the Southern District of New York (SDNY) did not pursue an investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell in 2016, despite pitches from victims' attorneys. The journalist, Stephen Brown, details meetings between attorneys and then-Assistant U.S. Attorney Maurene Comey and seeks official guidance on the office's decision-making at the time.

events.title: Victims' Attorneys Pitch SDNY on Epstein
events.description: Attorneys Stan Pottinger, Brad Edwards, and Peter Skinner met with then-AUSA Maurene Comey to pitch an investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's scheme, specifically for crimes committed in New York.

events.title: Attorneys Pitch SDNY on Perjury Charges
events.description: Attorneys David Boies and Stan Pottinger re-approached SDNY (presumably with AUSA Comey) to pitch charging Ghislaine Maxwell (and Jeffrey Epstein) with perjury, seen as a work-around to earlier legal concerns.

events.title: Miami Herald Investigation Published
events.description: The Miami Herald published articles about the Epstein case, after which SDNY, under U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman, opened an investigation.

keyFacts: In February 2016, victims' attorneys formally pitched the SDNY to investigate Jeffrey Epstein for crimes in New York, but the effort 'went nowhere.'

Then-AUSA Maurene Comey raised specific legal hurdles: establishing venue, the South Florida Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA), statute of limitations, and the tradition of not second-guessing another U.S. Attorney's office.
Later in 2016, attorneys David Boies and Stan Pottinger pitched the SDNY on charging Ghislaine Maxwell (and Epstein) with perjury based on her depositions, but that also was not pursued.
The SDNY eventually opened an investigation under U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman following the Miami Herald's reporting.
Ghislaine Maxwell has claimed in filings that she was the victim of a 'perjury trap' set by David Boies in cahoots with the SDNY.
